questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following represents the surface marking of the aortic valve?

options.a: Sternal end of left third costal cartilage
options.b: Sternal end of the right third costal cartilage
options.c: Beside the sternum in the left third intercostal space
options.d: Beside the sternum in right third intercostal space

questions.explanation:
The surface marking of aortic valve is beside the sternum in the left third intercostal space. 825 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: What is the surface marking of the mitral valve?

options.a: Behind the sternum end of the left 4th costal cartilage
options.b: Behind the sternal end of the right 4th costal cartilage
options.c: Left 4th intercostal space in midclavicular line
options.d: Left 3rd intercostal space in midclavicular line

questions.explanation:
The orifice of the mitral valve is level with the left half of the sternum opposite the left 4th costal 
cartilage and is represented by a line approximately 3 cm long and descending to the right.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient developed hoarseness due to left recurrent laryngeal nerve weakness. TTE revealed 
compression of the nerve by the enlarged base of the heart. Which of the following chambers 
is likely to be dilated?
questions.explanation:
The base of the heart is formed mainly by the left atrium. Enlargement of the left atrium can 
cause hoarseness due to compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. The base of the heart is a quadrilateral directed posteriorly. It is made of: • The left atrium mainly 826 
Sold by @itachibot • Small part of the right atrium • Proximal parts of superior vena cava, inferior vena cava, and pulmonary veins The base of the heart lies at the level of T5-T8 vertebrae in the supine position. The apex of the heart is formed by the left ventricle in the 5th intercostal space. Surfaces of the heart: • Sternocostal surface - Formed by the right atrium, right and left ventricles • Diaphragmatic surface - Formed mainly by the left ventricle • Left surface - Formed mainly of the left ventricle • Right surface - Formed mainly of the right atrium

questions.question:
Question 4: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures: 815 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium. The costal margin, xiphoid process, and the mid-clavicular line are seen in this image. The 
examiner draws a laterally convex line that extends from a level below the 2nd costal cartilage (as 
clued in by the sternal angle) i.e., 3rd costal cartilage to about 3 spaces below i.e., the 6th costal 
cartilage. This line is about 1.2 cms lateral to the sternal edge. These suggest that the region 
marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium. The projection of the cardiac borders, of an average adult, onto the anterior thoracic wall forms a 
trapezoid. This can be mapped out using the percussion method by looking for cardiac dullness. The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows: • Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal 
cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium. 827 
Sold by @itachibot • Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1–2 
cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium. • Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac 
apex which is located approximately 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal 
space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle. • Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the 
cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It 
corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a car accident. He 
sustained a severe injury to the anterior chest wall from the impact caused by the steering 
wheel. X-ray revealed fracture of the body of the sternum. Which of the following chambers of 
the heart is most likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
The area posterior to the sternum is occupied by the right ventricle and hence is most likely to be 
injured in this case. 828 
Sold by @itachibot The convex anterosuperior surface of the right ventricle makes up a large part of the sternocostal 
aspect of the heart, and is separated from the thoracic wall only by the pericardium.

questions.question:
Question 6: During the post-mortem heart examination of a patient, the resident palpates a muscular 
ridge, which is the site of origin of pectinate muscles. In which of the following chambers is 
the resident palpating this structure?
questions.explanation:
The structure being palpated by the resident is crista terminalis. It is present in the right atrium. It is a muscular ridge that runs anteriorly along the atrial wall from the opening of the superior 
vena cava to the opening of the inferior vena cava. It corresponds externally to sulcus terminalis. 
It is the site of origin of pectinate muscles. It divides the right atrium into a smooth posterior part and a rough anterior part. Both the vena 
cavae empty into the posterior smooth part. 829 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: The right border of the heart is formed by which of the following structures?
questions.explanation: The right border of the heart is formed of the right atrium. Borders of the heart: • Right border: Right atrium • Left border: Left ventricle mainly and to a slight extent by left atrial appendage • Inferior border: Right ventricle mainly and a small contribution by the left ventricle • Upper border: Left atrium, ascending aorta, and the pulmonary trunk.

questions.question:
Question 8: While doing the doppler USG of a fetal heart, you note blood flow from the right atrium to the 
left atrium. After the delivery, the connection eventually closes. What would form the floor of 
this structure after it closes?
questions.explanation:
The structure mentioned here is the foramen ovale through which blood passes from the right 
atrium to the left atrium as part of fetal circulation. It closes at delivery and later forms fossa 
ovalis. The floor of the fossa ovalis is formed by the septum primum. Fossa ovalis is an oval-shaped depression in the septal wall of the right atrium just above the 
opening of inferior vena cava. Its floor is formed by the remnant of septum primum. The limbus 
of fossa ovalis is the prominent rim of the depression which represents the remnant of septum 
secundum. 830 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: What is the location of the sinoatrial node?
questions.explanation:
The sinoatrial (SA) node is located at the upper part of the crista terminalis, at the junction of the 
superior vena cava opening to the right atrium. This is also the junction between the parts of the 
right atrium derived from sinus venosus and primitive atria. The Atrioventricular (AV) node lies at the lower back section of the interatrial septum near the 
opening of the coronary sinus. It is located in the center of the Koch triangle.

questions.question:
Question 10: A cardiologist is doing the AV node ablation procedure for AVNRT. While locating the AV 
node, he would look at all of the following landmarks forming its boundary except:
questions.explanation:
The AV node is present in the center of the triangle of Koch. The posterior leaflet of the tricuspid 
valve does not form its boundary. The triangle of Koch is found on the smooth posterior wall of the right atrium. It is bound by: • The coronary sinus • Tendon of Todaro • The septal cusp of the tricuspid valve The triangle of Koch can be seen in the image below bound by the dashed blue lines: 831 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following statements is false regarding the SA node?

options.a: It is located at the right border of ascending aorta
options.b: It contains specialized nodal cardiac muscle
options.c: It is supplied by the atrial branches of the right coronary artery
options.d: Action potential generated here does not have phase 1 or 2

questions.explanation:
Sino-atrial (SA) node is not located at the right border of the ascending aorta. It is located at the opening of the superior vena cava into the right atrium. It is called the 
'pacemaker' of the heart. It is supplied by the atrial branches of the right coronary artery. It 
contains specialized nodal cardiac muscle which spontaneously produces an electrical impulse. 
The action potential of these cells does not have phase 1 or 2.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 40-year-old man underwent coronary artery bypass grafting. During the procedure, the 
surgeon applied a clamp to the vessel lying anterior to the transverse pericardial sinus. 
Identify the vessel.
questions.explanation:
The aorta lies anterior to the transverse pericardial sinus. 832 
Sold by @itachibot The reflections of the serous pericardium are arranged as two tubes – one enclosing the aorta and 
the pulmonary trunk and the other enclosing the vena cavae and the four pulmonary veins. Oblique pericardial sinus: The zone of reflection surrounding the veins is J-shaped and the 
cul-de-sac formed within the J is the oblique pericardial sinus. This lies posterior to the left 
atrium. The image below shows the posterior view of the heart demonstrating the oblique and the 
transverse sinus. Transverse pericardial sinus: It is a passage between the two 'tubes'. The aorta and the pulmonary 
trunk lie anterior and the superior vena cava and the atria lie posterior to it. The pulmonary trunk divides into the right and left pulmonary arteries above the transverse 
sinus. Clinical significance: 833 
Sold by @itachibot During cardiac surgery, the transverse pericardial sinus allows a surgeon to isolate the pulmonary 
trunk and ascending aorta and apply a temporary ligature or clamp.

questions.question: Question 13: How many papillary muscles are there in the left ventricle?
questions.explanation: The left ventricle has 2 papillary muscles. There are 3 papillary muscles in the right ventricle: • Anterior, • Posterior • Septal muscles There are 2 papillary muscles in the left ventricle: • Anterior • Posterior

questions.question:
Question 14: What are Purkinje fibers? 818 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Purkinje fibers are modified cardiac muscles. The Purkinje network is subendocardial and the muscular excitation proceeds from endocardium 
to epicardium.

questions.question:
Question 15: A surgeon opens the pericardial sac anteriorly during surgery. He passes a surgical clamp 
through the transverse sinus. The circulation of blood in which of the following structures is 
stopped/diverted by his action?
questions.explanation:
During surgery, a clamp is passed through the transverse sinus. This stops/diverts the blood flow 
from the aorta and pulmonary trunk. The transverse pericardial sinus separates the arterial end of the heart tube from the venous end. 
Aorta and pulmonary trunk lie anterior to the sinus and the superior vena cava lies posterior to it. 
Therefore, during surgery, a clamp passed through the transverse sinus stops or diverts the blood 
flow from the aorta and pulmonary trunk. 834 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A cardiologist while reviewing a case of MI, notes that the patient has right dominant 
circulation. Which of the following determines coronary dominance?
questions.explanation:
Coronary dominance is determined by the posterior interventricular artery (PIVA). In about 65% of the population, the PIVA is given by the right coronary artery and this is called 
the right cardiac dominance. In 10% of the population, it is a branch of the left coronary artery alone, called the left cardiac 
dominance. In the remaining 25% population, it is given by both (balanced dominance).

questions.question:
Question 17: Coronary angiography of a patient revealed posterior interventricular artery branching from 
the circumflex artery. What would the arterial circulation in this patient be called?
questions.explanation:
If the circumflex artery gives off the posterior interventricular artery, then the arterial supply is 
called left dominant. In 65% of the population, the posterior interventricular artery (PIVA) is a branch of the right 
coronary artery and this is called the right dominance. In 10% of the population, PIVA is given by the circumflex artery (a branch of the left coronary 
artery) and this is called the left dominance. 835 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: 819 
Sold by @itachibot All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except

options.a: It's diameter is less than left coronary artery
options.b: It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
options.c: It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
options.d: Right conal artery is it's first branch

questions.explanation:
The right coronary artery does not give rise to the circumflex coronary artery. The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus (right coronary sinus) of the 
ascending aorta. It passes anteriorly and descends vertically in the coronary sulcus between the 
right atrium and the right ventricle. On reaching the inferior margin, it turns posteriorly and 
continues in the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and the base of the heart. The diameter of the right coronary artery is less than that of the left coronary artery. The right conal artery is, usually the first branch of the right coronary artery. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery and is the exclusive supplier 
to the right bundle branch. 836 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A 55-year-old man presented with angina. Coronary angiography revealed a block in the right 
coronary artery. Blood supply through which of the following arteries would not be affected?
questions.explanation:
The circumflex artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right coronary artery. Hence, 
blood supply through the circumflex artery won't be affected. The branches of the right coronary artery are: • Right conal artery - first branch of the right coronary artery • Artery of the SA node • Acute right marginal artery • Posterior interventricular artery (in 65% population) • Atrial and anterior and posterior ventricular branches

questions.question: Question 20: All of the following supply the marked structure except :
questions.explanation:
The structure marked is the right ventricle. It is not supplied by the diagonal artery. The diagonal artery is a branch of the anterior interventricular artery supplying the left ventricle. 
This is present in about 30-50% of the population. The right ventricle is mostly supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches such as the 
marginal artery. The anterior interventricular artery gives off 1-2 anterior right ventricular branches. 837 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient underwent angioplasty with a Sirolimus-eluting stent in the anterior 
interventricular artery. This artery is a branch of:
questions.explanation:
The anterior interventricular artery is a branch of the left coronary artery. The left coronary artery arises from the left aortic sinus (left posterior sinus) of the ascending 
aorta. It passes between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then runs in the coronary 
sulcus. It divides into its two terminal branches in the coronary sulcus. They are: • Anterior interventricular branch - also called the left anterior descending artery (LAD). • Circumflex branch - It gives a left marginal artery also called the obtuse marginal artery 
supplying the left ventricle. 838 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: In a patient with STEMI, nuclear stress test revealed poor blood supply to the anterior 
two-thirds of the interventricular septum. Which of the following blood vessels is most likely 
to be blocked?
questions.explanation:
The anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum is supplied by the left coronary artery. 
Hence, this artery is most likely blocked. The right coronary artery distribution supplies: • Right atrium • Right ventricle (except a small region to the right of the anterior interventricular groove) • A variable part of the diaphragmatic aspect of the left ventricle • Posteroinferior 1/3rd of the interventricular septum • Part of the left atrium • The conduction system, as far as the proximal parts of the right and left crura The left coronary artery distribution supplies: • Left atrium • Left ventricle • A narrow strip of the right ventricle • The anterior 2/3rd of the interventricular septum

questions.question:
Question 23: What is the arterial supply of the structure labelled in the picture with the blue dotted line? 821 
Sold by @itachibot

options.d: Artery from the left posterior aortic sinus

questions.explanation:
The image shows a triangle of Koch marked with blue dotted lines. The arterial supply to the 
triangle of Koch is from the right coronary artery in the majority of the population.

questions.question:
Question 24: A patient with a recent MI underwent coronary angiography, which revealed a block in the 
anterior interventricular artery. The infarction is likely to be present in which of the following 
regions of the heart?

options.b: Anterior wall of the left ventricle
options.d: Inferior surface of the right ventricle

questions.explanation:
839 
Sold by @itachibot The occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) will lead to the infarction of the anterior 
wall of the left ventricle. The left anterior descending artery also called the anterior interventricular artery supplies the 
anterior 2/3rd of the interventricular septum and the adjacent anterior wall of the left ventricle. Options A and D: The posterior interventricular artery supplies the posterior part of the 
interventricular septum and the inferior part of the right ventricle. Option C: The left lateral surface of the heart is supplied by the circumflex artery.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is not a tributary of the coronary sinus?
questions.explanation:
Anterior cardiac vein does not open into the coronary sinus. It drains directly into the right 
atrium. Tributaries of coronary sinus include the following: • Great cardiac vein • Middle cardiac vein • Small cardiac vein • Posterior cardiac vein • Oblique vein of the left atrium Thebsian vein/venae cordis minimae, anterior cardiac veins, and the right marginal vein drain 
directly into the right atrium. 840 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 26: Where does the great cardiac vein lie?

options.a: Anterior part of the coronary sulcus
options.b: Posterior part of the right coronary sulcus

questions.explanation:
The great cardiac vein lies in the anterior interventricular sulcus. The great cardiac vein begins at the cardiac apex, and ascends in the anterior interventricular 
groove to the atrioventricular groove, which it follows, passing to the left and posteriorly to enter 
the coronary sinus at its origin. The great cardiac vein accompanies the anterior interventricular artery (left anterior descending 
artery). 841 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 27: 822 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following statements is true regarding the coronary sinus?

options.a: It lies in the anterior part of coronary sulcus
options.b: It ends in the right atrium
options.c: It has venae cordis minimae as its tributaries
options.d: It develops from the right anterior cardinal vein

questions.explanation:
Coronary sinus ends in the right atrium. Coronary sinus develops from the left horn of the sinus venosus and lies in the posterior part of 
the atrioventricular groove. The sinus opens into the right atrium between the opening of the 
inferior vena cava and the right atrioventricular orifice. Venae cordis minimae drains directly into the nearest heart chamber (drains into all 4 chambers). 842 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 28: A 58-year-old man is undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting. The coronary angiography 
revealed total blockage of the posterior descending artery. While exposing this artery during 
the procedure, which accompanying vessel is most likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
The middle cardiac vein is present in the posterior interventricular groove accompanying the 
posterior descending artery, and hence is most likely to be injured in this case.

questions.question: Question 29: Which among the following is wrong about the venous drainage of the heart?

options.a: Coronary sinus is guarded by the Thebesian valve
options.b: Middle cardiac vein lies in the posterior atrioventricular groove
options.c: Great cardiac vein accompanies left anterior descending artery
options.d: Venae cordis minimae open into all 4 chambers

questions.explanation:
The middle cardiac veins lie in the posterior interventricular groove and not the posterior 
atrioventricular groove. Option A: The opening of the coronary sinus may be guarded by a semilunar valve of the coronary 
sinus, the Thebesian valve. 843 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: The great cardiac vein accompanies the anterior interventricular artery (left anterior 
descending artery) in the anterior interventricular groove. Option D: The venae cordis minimae / Thebesian veins open into all cardiac chambers.

questions.question:
Question 30: In a patient with thrombosis of the coronary sinus, which of the following cardiac veins are 
least likely to get dilated?
questions.explanation:
The anterior cardiac vein drains directly into the right atrium and not into the coronary sinus, 
hence, they might remain normal in coronary sinus thrombosis.

questions.question: Question 31: Which of these veins does not open into the sinus venarum?
questions.explanation:
Small cardiac vein does not open into the sinus venarum. It opens into the coronary sinus. Superior vena cava, coronary sinus, and the inferior vena cava open into the sinus venarum or the 
smooth posterior part of the right atrium.

questions.question: Question 32: Sympathetic innervation of heart is by
questions.explanation:
The sympathetic innervation of the heart is by T1-T5. The preganglionic sympathetic nerves to the heart arise from T1-T5. Some of these synapse in the 
upper thoracic sympathetic ganglia and some synapse in the cervical ganglia. The postganglionic 
fibres from these ganglia form the sympathetic cardiac nerves and innervate the heart.

questions.question: Question 33: Where is cardiac ganglion situated?
questions.explanation:
The cardiac ganglion of Wrisberg is present in the superficial cardiac plexus immediately below 
and slightly in front of the arch of aorta to the right of the ligamentum arteriosum. 844 
Sold by @itachibot Lungs and Pleura
